As the primary component of natural gas, methane is an essential raw material in chemical industries. Meanwhile, it is also a powerful greenhouse gas that causes severe global warming effects. On-site conversion of methane to value-added chemicals and fuels, especially transportable and storable methanol, is a dream reaction. However, traditional methane oxidation methods will consume huge amounts of energy and lead to carbon emission. Utilizing only renewable solar energy, photocatalysis has attracted increasing interest for methane oxidation to methanol due to its low energy consumption and environmental friendliness. In this work, a perspective on photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol is proposed by analyzing the oxygen source of methanol, which can be a new strategy to modulate the methane oxidation reaction. It provides a new angle to understand the mechanism of the reaction, and inspirations for optimizing the efficiency and selectivity of methanol production from photocatalytic methane oxidation. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methane oxidation Photocatalysis Methanol production Oxygen source Selectivity Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Methane (CH4) is the primary constituent of natural gas. In the field of chemical industries, CH4 has been a critical raw material for manufacturing valuable chemicals [1–3]. However, methane has a significant impact on the environment and is the most abundant greenhouse gas second to carbon dioxide (CO2), with its impact on global warming 25 times that of CO2 [4]. What is more, as methane is mined primarily in remote areas, the gas must be transported over long distances. Liquification of methane gas is unavoidable for transportation considering its low boiling-point (109 K) at atmospheric pressure [5]. Therefore, on-site conversion of methane to value-added chemicals and fuels, especially transportable and storable derivatives, such as methanol (CH3OH), is highly desirable from the aspects of both chemical synthesis and environment [2,6]. Among various products of CH4 conversion, CH3OH is one of the most desirable products. It can act as a versatile C1 building block for higher-value chemicals in the chemical industry. What is more, it is also a promising fuel due to the high energy density [7,8]. Therefore, methane oxidation to methanol has attracted growing attention and is expected to have broad development prospects. From the perspective of chemical structure, methane has the strongest C-H bond among hydrocarbons (436 kJ mol−1). Therefore, breaking the C-H bond in methane is a significant challenge to synthesize other fuels from methane [9–11]. For CH4, the energy level of the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) is low, and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) is high. Therefore, it is difficult to remove the electrons from HOMO for oxidation and to donate electrons to LUMO for reduction, which means that CH4 is inherently extremely stable [6]. Thermal catalytic oxidation is the traditional method to achieve methane oxidation to methanol. However, thermal catalytic process is energy-intensive, and emits huge amounts of CO2, and has high risk of overoxidation. Electrocatalytic methane oxidation is another common method to oxidate methane to methanol. However, it needs expensive Pt as electrode, and generally consumes strong acids as electrolyte, both of which are undesirable in terms of cost and operation. In addition, the conversion rate and selectivity of methane are greatly affected by temperature, and there is unavoidable competition between water oxidation and methane overoxidation in electrocatalytic oxidation [6]. In comparison, photocatalytic partial oxidation of methane (POM) has some advantages over the thermocatalysis and electrocatalysis. First, photocatalytic POM utilizes only solar energy, which is a clean and direct energy source, without environmental impact of thermocatalysis or pre-conversion of other energy sources to electricity for electrocatalysis. Second, the conversion of methane does not vary greatly with temperature, allowing a mild synthetic process at room temperature with less energy input compared with high-temperature thermocatalytic synthesis. Third, the reaction system is of low cost and operation complexity. In this perspective, we will focus on the photocatalytic methanol production by POM. In recent years, some articles have reviewed the photocatalytic oxidation of methane to methanol. Tian et al. discussed photocatalysts, oxidants, sacrificial reagents, and CH4 activation mechanisms from the aspects of semiconductor systems and non-semiconductor systems [12]. Villa et al. summarized that the design of nanostructured photocatalysts have a significant impact on the oxidation of methane to methanol [13]. Although these reviews summarized some recent progress in photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol, they do not specifically discuss the oxygen source of methanol in the methane oxidation process. In fact, oxygen source during methanol formation is key to understanding the reaction mechanism. In this perspective, the oxidants and oxygen sources (O2, H2O, H2O2, NOx, etc.) are discussed to provide a unique insight into the activation of CH4 and the selectivity of photocatalytic POM to CH3OH. 2 Fundamentals of photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol The principle of photocatalysis is to use semiconductor materials to utilize light energy to drive chemical reactions. When light energy is greater than or equal to the energy gap of the semiconductor, the electrons in the valence band (VB) will be excited to the conduction band (CB). The electrons can a reduction reaction to happen on the condition that the reaction potential is less negative than the VB, and holes will oxidize substances with a less positive potential. Meanwhile, it is well known that recombination of electrons and holes will lead to a lower efficiency and productivity due to less reactive species for redox reactions. Without oxygen source in the system, the main products of photocatalytic methane oxidation are ethane and hydrogen, while with proper source of oxygen, liquid oxygenates (e.g. HCOOH, CH3OH, CH3OOH) can be obtained. However, care must be taken that highly active oxygen species on the surface of photocatalyst may result in overoxidation of methane to undesirable CO2/CO. In literature, O2, H2O, H2O2, and NOx have been demonstrated to be potential oxygen sources for methanol from photocatalytic methane oxidation. As illustrated in Fig. 1, the mechanism of these reactions generally involves the cleavage of C-H bond of CH4 to form •CH3 radical as a result of oxidation by holes, and the direct/indirect formation of •OH (H2O, H2O2, and NOx) or •OOH radical (O2) at the same time. The reaction of •CH3 radical and •OH or •OOH radical produces the dream product CH3OH or CH3OOH as primary product, and CH3OOH can be further reduced to generate CH3OH as final product. The source of oxygen in the methanol product has been mostly investigated by isotope labeling experiments, which can be identified in the following section. 3 The oxygen sources of methanol from POM 3.1 Photocatalytic POM to methanol with O2 3.1.1 Semiconductor/metal cocatalyst systems Studies have demonstrated that typical oxide semiconductors, such as ZnO and TiO2, loaded with metal cocatalysts, can activate O2 into highly reactive oxygen species, ultimately leading to serious overoxidation of CH4 [14–16]. However, in a recent work, ZnO photocatalysts loaded with suitable cocatalysts (Pt, Pd, Au, Ag) were designed to promote the conversion of methane to methanol [17]. At room temperature, O2 was the only oxidizer for methane oxidation in water. The surface-active oxygen (hole center) of photo-excited ZnO dominates the breakage of C–H bond in CH4 to •CH3 radical. It is critical to control the activation of O2 over cocatalysts to produce mild reactive oxygen species, •OOH radicals, with the assistance of protonation of water. This allows the selective generation of liquid oxygenates, and avoids overoxidation of CH4 to CO2 and CO. In addition, it was found that Pt and Pd were more selective for the production of CH3OH or H2O (4-electron process), compared with Au and Ag favorable for CH3OOH or H2O2 (2-electron process). The specific reaction process was shown in Fig. 2. In the isotope experiments, 100 % CH3 18OH was obtained with 18O2 and H2 16O in the reaction system, while no CH3 18OH was detected when using 16O2 and H2 18O. Therefore, it can be concluded that O in the CH3OH is entirely from O2 rather than H2O. More recently, ZnO photocatalysts loaded with highly dispersed dual Au and Cu have also been developed for photocatalytic POM to methanol [18]. Among all the samples of different Au:Cu ratios, Au0.2Cu0.15–ZnO has the highest selectivity of methanol and suppresses overoxidation of products. The mechanism is that Cu species play a role as photo-induced electron mediators to promote the activation of O2 to •OOH, and Au is an efficient hole acceptor to enhance H2O oxidation to •OH. As shown in Fig. 3, isotopic measurement revealed that O2 was the only oxygen source for CH3OH and other oxygenates, while H2O played a role to promote CH4 activation. However, the performance of ZnO is hampered by its stability. In this regard, TiO2 is a more promising photocatalyst for methane conversion to methanol, as it is very stable and has excellent catalytic performance [19]. Song et al. synthesized dual-cocatalyst (nanometals (Au, Pd, Ag, Pt) and cobalt oxide) modified TiO2 photocatalysts [20]. The photocatalysts can promote the conversion of methane to methanol at the room temperature. The nanometals can promote the separation of photo-excited electron and reduction of O2 to promote the conversion CH4 to CH3OH, while the CoO x prevents further oxidation of CH3OH to HCHO and CO2, which maintains the high selectivity of CH3OH. By isotope labelling, GC-MS spectra confirmed that O2 was the only oxygen source of the formed primary products (CH3OOH and CH3OH) in the reaction. Another recent study revealed that optimized {001}-dominated TiO2 with Ag cocatalyst had a durable CH3OH yield of 4.8 mmol g−1 h−1 and a selectivity of ∼80 %, which are much higher than those of {101}-dominated TiO2 with Ag cocatalyst [21]. This study provides inspiration for controlled CH4 reforming to CH3OH by regulating the generation of photo-induced oxygen vacancies. Interestingly, dimeric copper centers supported on graphitic carbon nitride (denoted as Cu2@C3N4) were synthesized for both thermocatalytic and photocatalytic POM [22]. Compared with thermocatalysis using H2O2 as oxidants, photocatalytic methane oxidation using Cu2@C3N4 utilizes O2, which will be reduced to peroxide species as oxidants for POM. In addition, the photon excitation is also believed to enhance the methane activation compared with the thermocatalytic process. The photoexcited electrons in the g-C3N4 substrate leads to the reduction of O2 to form H2O2, and H2O2 migrates onto the dicopper-oxo center activated to form • OOH or • OH. Meanwhile, the holes transfer from the g-C3N4 substrate to the dicopper-oxo center, where CH4 is activated and oxidized to form • CH3. Then, the oxygen species recombine with • CH3 to form methyl oxygenates. According to the reaction mechanism, the O in the CH3OH product comes from O2 ( Fig. 4). 3.1.2 Bismuth-based photocatalyst systems In recent years, bismuth-based photocatalysts have become attracted increasing interest. Bismuth photocatalysts have hybridized band structures between Bi 6 s and O 2p orbitals, the enhanced charge carrier mobility due to a less localized character of the s orbitals and a decrease in the band gap. BiVO4 is an n-type semiconductor with a narrow band gap energy (2.4–2.5 eV), which can absorb visible light up to 500 nm. Quantum-sized bismuth vanadate nanoparticles (q-BiVO4) have been demonstrated to be a promising photocatalyst for the conversion of methane to methanol [23]. Under visible light irradiation, q-BiVO4 is excited and produce • OH radical to break C-H bond of CH4, and the generated • CH3 radical reacts with proton and electron to produce CH3OH as the dominant product. It should be noticed that CH3OH will be further oxidized to HCHO under UV light irradiation. With an increasing volume of H2O, the selectivity of CH3OH increases from 20 % to 62.8 % with the yield of 6.8 mmol g−1, and less HCHO is formed. Therefore, increasing the volume of water solvent is an effective strategy to increase selectivity of methanol. Isotope tests revealed that the O in CH3OH product absolutely originated from O2 rather than H2O, indicating O2 as the only oxygen source for CH3OH formation. Apart from BiVO4, Bi2O3 is also a promising photocatalyst for CH4 oxidation, as its VB position is favorable to produce •OH (Eqs. (1)–(3)), which is beneficial for CH3OH formation and a CB unfavorable to produce O2•-, which is inclined to overoxidize CH4 [24]. CH4 oxidation with isotopically labeled oxygen (18O2) results revealed that O2 was the oxygen source for the CH3OH (Eqs. 4–5). (1) Bi 2 O 3 ( s ) → hv ( visible − light ) h + + e − (2) H 2 O + h + → OH ( aq ) ∙ + H + ( aq ) (3) CH 4 aq + OH aq ∙ → CH 3 aq ∙ + H 2 O l (4) CH 3 ( aq ) ∙ + O 2 ( g ) → CH 3 O 2 ( aq ) ∙ (5) CH 3 O 2 ( aq ) ∙ + OH ( aq ) ∙ → CH 3 OH ( aq ) 3.2 Photocatalytic POM to methanol with H2O 3.2.1 WO3 systems WO3 is a stable, safe, and moderate oxidizing semiconductor material, which can active the C-H in methane, and therefore, is a promising catalyst of methane oxidation to methanol. In comparison with TiO2 and NiO, WO3 showed the largest conversion rate of methane to methanol under UV laser irradiation [25]. In fact, the hydroxyl group on the surface of WO3 is the main reason for promoting methanol formation in photocatalytic methane oxidation. In order to study the importance of hydroxyl groups on WO3 surface for methane oxidation, WO3/F was used to evaluate the role of hydroxyl groups in methane oxidation [26]. Since free hydroxyl radicals (•OHfree) and hydroxyl radicals (•OHads) play different roles in the reactions, there are two possible mechanisms in the reaction system. In the first mechanism, the photo-generated holes react with H2O to produce •OHfree. Photo-generated holes or •OHfree can oxidize CH4 to CH3 •, CH3 • can reacts with H2O and •OHfree to produce CH3OH. In the second mechanism, the photo-generated holes react with H2O adsorbed on the WO3 surface to produce •OHads (Eqs. (6)–(10)). •OHads can oxidize CH4 to CH3 •, CH3 • can reacts with H2O and •OHads to produce CH3OH (Eqs. (11), (13)). In the process, •OHfree can promote to produce C2H6 in the system (Eq. (12)). (6) W O 3 → hv e CB − + h VB + (7) e CB − + H + → H . (8) H . + H . → H 2 (9) h VB + + H 2 O ads → H O ads . + H + (10) h VB + + H O ads − → H O ads . (11) CH 4 + H O ads . → CH 3 . + H 2 O (12) CH 3 . + CH 3 . → C 2 H 6 (13) CH 3 . + H 2 O ads → CH 3 OH + 1 2 H 2 Fluorination on WO3 surface has a negative impact on the production of methanol. As shown in Fig. 5, after fluorination, F occupies the location of •OH on the WO3 surface, and therefore the formation of CH3OH by •OH reacting with CH3 • was significantly decreased and CH3 • radicals easily couple to form C2H6. La doping on the mesoporous WO3 surface was reported to improve the selectivity and yield of methanol [27]. Compared with pure WO3, WO3/La has 50 % higher methanol selectivity, as La plays a multiple role in the system. First, La can prevent the structure being destroyed after removing silica support during the synthesis. Second, La can promote the adsorption of water on the surface of WO3, which can facilitate the formation of OH group and further the production of CH3OH. Ag+ impregnated WO3 was also prepared to explore the mechanism of methane conversion to methanol [28]. The production of H2 and concentration of •OH radicals increased when increasing the loading amount of Ag+ (0–5 %) on WO3 surface. The reason is that methanol molecules compete with water molecules for photo-generated holes, which results in its simultaneous degradation. Therefore, it is essential to remove methanol continuously to increase the yield of methanol and prevent the further oxidation of methanol after formation via POM. 3.2.2 Bismuth-based photocatalyst systems Among bismuth-based photocatalysts, Bi2WO6 and BiVO4 have been two of the most studied oxides for photocatalytic applications due to favorable properties [29,30]. It was observed that activity of BiVO4 microcrystals for photocatalytic POM to methanol showed facet-dependent phenomenon [31]. The results suggest that controlling the morphologies of microcrystals can tune the conversion of methane to methanol. Thick platelet and bipyramidal BiVO4 have a higher selectivity of methanol than thin platelet, with bipyramidal BiVO4 showing the highest selectivity and activity for methanol production. The bipyramids combine efficient extraction of holes from nearly the entire surface of the microcrystal and intermediate surface reactivity, leading to high selectivity for POM. Furthermore, the performance of bismuth-based photocatalysts, Bi2WO6, BiVO4, and coupled Bi2WO6/TiO2–P25 was compared for photocatalytic POM to methanol [32]. Results turned out that BiVO4 has the highest selectivity of methanol and better stability than Bi2WO6 and coupled Bi2WO6/TiO2–P25. Interestingly, although the methane conversion rate of coupled Bi2WO6/TiO2–P25 was higher than that of Bi2WO6, overoxidation of CH4 was more likely to occur, which was not desirable for methanol production. In addition, as Fe3+ can react with H2O2 to produce •OH, O2 can increase •OH concentration and increases availability of holes in the valence band, adding Fe3+ or O2 in the system also led to boosted methane conversion and unwished overoxidation. 3.2.3 Zeolite system Zeolites are porous aluminosilicates with special frameworks of regular channels and unique features favorable for industrial processes [33]. Some active guests can be put inside the framework of zeolite to improve the catalytic performance. Some heteroatoms, such as Ti, Cr, V, and Cu, have been dispersed into zeolites structure to make new photocatalyst. For example, V-containing β zeolites have been explored as photocatalyst to study the selectivity and yield of photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol [34]. Beta zeolite (H-BEA) was proven to be the efficient photocatalyst material for the oxidation of methane. The addition of V and Bi-V to the zeolite framework significantly decreases the amount of acid sites due to the formation of V2O5 on the surface, which is able to block the acid Al–O units and part of the Si–OH groups, thus improving the selectivity to less oxidized products (e.g. CH3OH). The most significant result was that BiVO4/V2O5/zeolite heterojunction showed a complete selectivity to methanol. 3.2.4 Composite photocatalyst systems Single-component photocatalysts suffer from many inherent drawbacks, such as narrow light absorption, high charge carrier recombination rate, and low quantum efficiency, and stability [35]. Therefore, some studies seek to fabricate composite photocatalyst systems to overcome the shortcomings. RuO x decorated ZnO/CeO2 photocatalyst was designed to promote the conversion of methane to methanol [8]. ZnO can active C-H in methane because of spontaneous polarization and prevent overoxidation of methane. CeO2 can improve the performance and stability of photocatalyst. RuO x clusters can reduce defects in ZnO/CeO2 to suppress the CO generation and facilitate the generation of hydroxyl radical (•OH) which can effectively activate CH4 and avoid overoxidation. As a result, a high selectivity of 98 % was achieved for photocatalytic CH4 oxidation to methanol. 3.3 Photocatalytic POM to methanol with H2O and O2 Au single atoms modified black phosphorus (Au1/BP) nanosheets were synthesized for methane conversion to methanol [36]. O2 can be activated by BP in the dark (Eq. 14). The electrons from the VB of BP were excited by photons, reacted with O2 at the triplet ground states (3O2) and generated O2 − (Eq. 15). O2 − recombined the photo-generated holes to form the excited O2 at the singlet states, 1O2. 1O2 reacted with H2O to form OH* and HOO* (can form •OH radicals by splitting, Eqs. (16)–(17)), and then react with CH4 to form water and CH3* stabilized by an Au atom (Eq. (18)). The combination of OH* and CH3* on the Au atom led to the formation of CH3OH (Eq. (19)) with an energy barrier of 1.10 eV, which was identified as the rate-limiting step of the reaction. Isotopic labelling experiment was carried out to detect oxygen source of CH3OH by using H2 18O and 32O2. It turned out that both CH3 18OH and CH3 16OH were detected, suggesting that both H2O and O2 were oxygen sources of CH3OH in this system. (14) O 2 + 3 P → P = O + P − O − P (15) O 2 3 e − → O 2 − (16) O 2 1 H 2 O → HO O * + O H * (17) HO O * → ∙ OH + O * (18) CH 4 * + P = O → CH 3 * + P − OH (19) CH 3 * + O H * → CH 3 OH A photocatalyst consisted of mono-iron hydroxyl sites within a metal–organic framework (PMOF-RuFe(OH)) has been developed to promote the conversion of methane to methanol under visible light [37]. With both H2O and O2 flowing, the selectivity of methanol was 100 %. Confined mono-iron hydroxyl sites can lower the barrier for C–H bond activation by binding CH4 through an [Fe–OH···CH4] intermediate. When H2O was absent or anhydrous benzene was used as solvent, CO2 was the only product of CH4 oxidation, suggesting overoxidation of CH4. When using H2O as solvent, the selectivity and yield of CH3OH increased. Using H2 18O/16O2 for isotopic labeling experiments further validated the involvement of both H2O and O2 in CH4 oxidation. 75 % of CH3 16OH and 25 % of CH3 18OH were detected, indicating both H2O and O2 provided oxygen for CH3OH product. 3.4 Photocatalytic POM to methanol with H2O2 For some photocatalysts, their band structures may not possess enough oxidizing potential to generate hydroxyl radicals (·OH) from water. In this scenario, it can be an effective strategy to involve H2O2 to produce·OH radicals for methane oxidation, as reported by Taylor and Noceti in 2020 [38]. H2O2 can be either externally added to the system or in-situ produced by photocatalytic reaction, such as water oxidation. It should be noted that an appropriate amount of·OH (externally added) or a gentle path to produce·OH (in-situ produced) should be the key factors for selective POM to methanol [6]. 3.4.1 Externally added H2O2 Fe cocatalyst loaded onto anatase TiO2 was synthesized using a rapid and facile impregnation method [39]. Due to the lower CB potential of iron oxide than TiO2, photo-generated electrons of TiO2 transferred to the CB of iron oxide. After reduction by the electron on iron oxide, H2O2 was decomposed into a ·OH radical and OH- ion. Meanwhile, CH4 reacted with photo-generated holes in the VB of TiO2 to form methyl radicals (·CH3), which further combined with ·OH radical to form CH3OH ( Fig. 6). In this system, ·OH radical from H2O2 is the main oxygen source for methanol. Similarly, dispersed amorphous FeOOH coupling with ordered mesoporous WO3 (m-WO3) was synthesized on KIT-6 silica hard template. Photo-induced holes on the VB of m-WO3 can active the methane to produce methyl radicals (·CH3), while photo-induced holes on FeOOH can decompose H2O2 to produce hydroxyl radicals (·OH). ·OH radical was the main oxidant to produce methanol, and the oxygen source of CH3OH was dominantly H2O2. In addition, dispersed gold on the tungsten trioxide (Au1/WO3) exhibited similar reaction steps on the Au1/WO3 surface for photocatalytic CH4 oxidation to CH3OH [40]. It is worth mentioning that the Au1 species have the tip-enhanced local electrons field to promote C-H cleavage to produce methanol. In addition, as CH3OH has a low adsorption energy on Au1, CH3OH overoxidation was avoided and thus the selectivity of CH3OH was increased. Interestingly, H2O2 can decompose into ∙OH on two neighboring Ce (III) atoms and decompose into ∙OOH on Ce (IV) in cerium dioxide (CeO2) nanowires supported rhodium (Rh) single-atom (SAs Rh-CeO2 NWs) [41]. ∙H radical will combine with lattice O of CeO2 ([O]) connected with the Ce (IV) in CeO2 NWs to form ∙[O]H. The adsorbed CH4 on Rh SAs can be oxidized by ∙OH radical into ∙CH3 and H2O. Then, CH3OOH and CH3[O]H will be formed through ∙CH3 reacting with the ∙OOH and ∙[O]H radicals. According to the reaction mechanism, the oxygen sources of CH3OOH and CH3[O]H are both H2O2 and lattice O. The reaction process was illustrated in Fig. 7. Highly dispersed transition metal atoms (Fe, Co, Cu) on crystalline carbon nitrides (PHI) were also prepared for photocatalytic POM in the presence of H2O2 at mild temperature [42]. After decomposition, H2O2 will form Cu-OH bond and ∙OH radicals. ∙OH radical will react with CH4 to form ∙CH3, and the Cu-OH bonds can react with ∙CH3 to produce CH3OH ( Fig. 8). The process can avoid the overoxidation of CH4 and thus increase the selectivity of CH3OH. In addition, study has reported that both H2O2 and H2O worked as the oxygen sources of CH3OH using fluffy free carbon nitride photocatalysts [43]. Isotope tracing experiments (H2 18O and H2 16O2) revealed that the ratio of CH3 18OH in the products was estimated to be 13.5 %. As H2O2 produces·OH very slowly, H2O has more opportunities to react with·CH3 radicals to produce CH3OH. 3.4.2 In-situ produced H2O2 Although it is a common strategy to obtain·OH radicals from the decomposition of externally added H2O2, it should be noted that only the catalyst-surface bound·OH species are mild enough to be highly selective for POM to methanol. Excess free·OH radicals may cause further oxidation or even mineralization [6]. Therefore, Zhou et al. introduce Cu species into polymeric carbon nitride (PCN) to form a unique photocatalyst (Cu-0.5/PCN) which can achieve in-situ generation (via water oxidation) and decomposition (to·OH radical) of H2O2 to control the amount of·OH radical [6]. As the holes in the VB of Cu-0.5/PCN cannot oxidize H2O into·OH, the generation of·OH was attributed to the decomposition of in-situ formed H2O2 by two-electron water oxidation pathway [44]. Although the main product using Cu-0.5/PCN is ethanol rather than methanol using pristine PCN, the strategy of in-situ producing H2O2 can be widely referenced and modulated for methane oxidation. 3.5 Photocatalytic POM to methanol with NOx It has been demonstrated in some experiments of thermocatalytic oxidation of methane that NOx may become possible oxidants to improve the selectivity of methanol in the process of oxidizing methane to methanol [45]. Nitrite ions (NO2 -) were utilized as oxidant to promote conversion of methane to methanol using BiVO4 photocatalyst [46]. As a UV filter, they have the function to slightly inhibit the photolysis of water, finally leading to the formation of ˙OH (Eqs. (20)–(21)). However, on the other hand, as a source and scavenger of free ˙OH radicals, they can balance the concentration of ˙OH (Eq. (22)) to avoid overoxidation and suppress the formation of ethane by coupling. (20) NO 2 − + hv → N ∙ + O ∙ − (21) O ∙ − + H 2 O ↔ OH ∙ + OH − (22) NO 2 − + OH ∙ → NO 2 ∙ + OH − What is more, NO has also been reported to provide O for photocatalytic POM to methanol, which turned out to be dependent on the local structure of the V-oxide species of designed V-MCM-41 (mesoporous molecular sieves) as photocatalyst [47]. In fact, the charge transfer excited states of the isolated tetrahedral V-oxide species supported on the catalyst surface provided active sites for photocatalytic POM to methanol. The state-of-the-art of photocatalytic POM to methanol from the perspective of oxygen source is summarized in Table 1. 4 Challenges and future perspectives The conversion of methane into methanol has been widely recognized as a dream reaction in chemical industry. Utilizing only solar energy to achieve this reaction can be a holy grail, in comparison with the high energy consumption and carbon emission of thermocatalysis, and the premature design and expensive noble-metal electrode of photoelectrocatalysis. Although the research in this direction is surging forward, it is still a significant challenge to achieve photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol with high efficiency and selectivity. In this work, we provided a new perspective on photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol. By analyzing the oxygen source of methanol product mostly by isotopic labeling experiments, the reaction mechanism can be better understood. It is clear that when no other oxygen-containing substances exist in the system, H2O is the only source of O in methanol product. However, although the oxygen source of methanol in most studies is only O2 when O2 is used as the oxidant with the presence of H2O, some studies show that a small part of the oxygen source comes from H2O. What is more, the oxygen source is mainly H2O2 when it is used as an oxidant, but there still exists a small portion of H2O originated methanol. However, when H2O is the only source of oxygen, heating is generally needed (55–70 ℃) and the productivity and efficiency of photocatalytic POM to methanol is low (<100 μmol g −1 h −1). In comparison, with O2 or H2O2 as the source of oxygen, the reaction can occur at room temperature with a much higher productivity (>2000 μmol g −1 h −1 (O2), 200–1000 μmol g −1 h −1 (externally added H2O2), and ∼20 μmol g −1 h −1 (in-situ produced H2O2)). What is more, the past 3 years have witnessed excitingly high selectivity (95–100 %) of methanol production from photocatalytic POM for some photocatalytic systems using these common oxygen sources. Meanwhile, NOx has also demonstrated some promise as oxygen source with methanol selectivity > 87 % despite low methanol productivity (< 5 μmol g −1 h −1). In a summary, seeing from the state-of-the-art, O2 seems to be the most promising source of oxygen from the aspects of both productivity and selectivity. However, future research on using O2 and other oxygen sources may provide further progress and new insights. However, due to technical limitations, the isotope is impure, and the concentration of the labeled isotope cannot reach 100 %. In addition, isotope exchange reaction is another important factor to influence the accuracy of isotope labelling in the experiments, lowering the temperature and optimizing the reaction device are effective ways to limit the isotope exchange reaction, but lowering the temperature will reduce the conversion rate of methane. Therefore, how to adjust the temperature to reduce the influence of isotope exchange reaction on the interpretation of oxygen source and reduce the influence on the reaction conversion rate is the problem worthy of discussion. Moreover, other catalytic processes, such as thermocatalysis, can provide reference for photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol. For example, Cu-exchanged mordenite zeolite (CuMOR) catalyst was an excellent thermocatalyst, with the productivity stabilized at 0.202 mol CH3OH per mole Cu, and selectivity of methanol 97 % [50]. The study demonstrates that Cu-O-Cu core is the crucial in the catalytic process, and the reactive oxygen species in the Cu-O-Cu core can react with methane to generate methoxy groups and reduce Cu2+ to Cu1+. As mentioned above, Cu2@C3N4 can be used as both thermocatalyst and photocatalyst for methanol production from methane oxidation [22] and zeolite-based photocatalysts have been reported for POM to methanol [34]. We expect that interdisciplinary research will break through the bottlenecks of efficiency and selectivity of photocatalytic POM to methanol for practical implementation. Dr. Haijiao Lu obtained her bachelor’s degree in Science from Nankai University (China) and in Engineering from Tianjin University (China) in 2014. Supervised by Academician of Chinese Academy of Engineering Prof. Jingkang Wang, she obtained PhD degree from Tianjin University (China) in 2019. During her PhD, she also worked as a visiting PhD student at University of Cambridge (UK). She worked as a postdoctoral research fellow at the Australian National University in 2019-2021, and then at the University of Queensland (UQ) with Australian Laureate Fellow Prof. Lianzhou Wang from 2021. Her research is characterized by interdisciplinary feature, which lies at the intersection of materials science, photo(electro)catalysis, and chemical engineering. She has been working as an ARC DECRA Research Fellow at UQ from 2023. Lianzhou Wang is Professor and Australian Research Council (ARC) Australian Laureate Fellow in School of Chemical Engineering, Director of Nanomaterials Centre (Nanomac), and Senior Group Leader of Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology (AIBN), UQ. He received his PhD degree from Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 1999. Before joining UQ in 2004, he has worked at two leading national research institutions (NIMS and AIST) of Japan as a research fellow for five years. Since joining UQ, he has worked as ARC Queen Elizabeth II Fellow (2006), Senior Lecturer (2007), Associate Professor (2010), Professor (2012-now) and ARC Future Fellow (2012-2016), and is now an ARC Australian Laureate Fellow (2019-2024) at Chemical Engineering School and AIBN. Professor Wang's research focuses on the synthesis, characterization and application of semiconductor nanomaterials for use in renewable energy conversion/storage systems including photocatalysts for solar hydrogen and valuable chemical production, rechargeable batteries and low-cost solar cells.

coredata.dc:description: As the primary component of natural gas, methane is an essential raw material in chemical industries. Meanwhile, it is also a powerful greenhouse gas that causes severe global warming effects. On-site conversion of methane to value-added chemicals and fuels, especially transportable and storable methanol, is a dream reaction. However, traditional methane oxidation methods will consume huge amounts of energy and lead to carbon emission. Utilizing only renewable solar energy, photocatalysis has attracted increasing interest for methane oxidation to methanol due to its low energy consumption and environmental friendliness. In this work, a perspective on photocatalytic methane oxidation to methanol is proposed by analyzing the oxygen source of methanol, which can be a new strategy to modulate the methane oxidation reaction. It provides a new angle to understand the mechanism of the reaction, and inspirations for optimizing the efficiency and selectivity of methanol production from photocatalytic methane oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Can we achieve efficient photocatalytic partial oxidation of methane to methanol: A perspective on oxygen reaction pathways
